articles.headline: ‘They’re Death Pits’: Virus Claims at Least 7,000 Lives in U.S. Nursing Homes
articles.snippet: More than six weeks after the first coronavirus deaths in a nursing home, outbreaks unfold across the country. About a fifth of U.S. virus deaths are linked to nursing facilities.
articles.abstract: More than six weeks after the first coronavirus deaths in a nursing home, outbreaks unfold across the country. About a fifth of U.S. virus deaths are linked to nursing facilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first warning of the devastation that the coronavirus could wreak inside American nursing homes came in late February, when residents of a facility in suburban Seattle perished, one by one, as families waited helplessly outside.
articles.byline: By Farah Stockman, Matt Richtel, Danielle Ivory and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Surprising Poll Results: People Are Now Happy to Pick Up the Phone
articles.snippet: Pollsters are used to having their calls screened. But when everyone is stuck at home, a stranger with some survey questions can be a lifeline.
articles.abstract: Pollsters are used to having their calls screened. But when everyone is stuck at home, a stranger with some survey questions can be a lifeline.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a straightforward telephone survey of New Yorkers, a series of questions about the effects of the coronavirus crisis, and it was meant to take just a few minutes. But a strange thing kept happening. Many of the people who answered the phone wanted to keep talking — about their loneliness, about their sadness, about their fears for the future — even after the questions had stopped.
articles.byline: By Giovanni Russonello and Sarah Lyall

articles.headline: Trump Encourages Protest Against Governors Who Have Imposed Virus Restrictions
articles.snippet: The president’s stark departure from his message on Thursday night, when he announced guidelines for governors to reopen their states and said they would “call your own shots,” suggested he was ceding any semblance of national leadership on the pa...
articles.abstract: The president’s stark departure from his message on Thursday night, when he announced guidelines for governors to reopen their states and said they would “call your own shots,” suggested he was ceding any semblance of national leadership on the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday openly encouraged right-wing protests of social distancing restrictions in states with stay-at-home orders, a day after announcing guidelines for how the nation’s governors should carry out an orderly reopening of their communities on their own timetables.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Sarah Mervosh

articles.headline: Who Owes You a Refund? Should You Even Ask?
articles.snippet: Airlines? For sure. Vrbo? Probably. But what about your child’s summer camp?
articles.abstract: Airlines? For sure. Vrbo? Probably. But what about your child’s summer camp?
articles.lead_paragraph: Among the financially unlucky right now, one question reigns supreme: Which bills can I simply not pay and for how long?

articles.headline: How Millions of Women Became the Most Essential Workers in America
articles.snippet: One in three jobs held by women has been designated as essential.
articles.abstract: One in three jobs held by women has been designated as essential.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every day, Constance Warren stands behind the cold cuts counter at a grocery store in New Orleans, watching the regular customers come and go.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: As Amazon Rises, So Does the Opposition
articles.snippet: Stacy Mitchell knew that taking on a trillion-dollar company would be a lopsided fight. But the pandemic has not only made Amazon more essential. It has also made it vulnerable.
articles.abstract: Stacy Mitchell knew that taking on a trillion-dollar company would be a lopsided fight. But the pandemic has not only made Amazon more essential. It has also made it vulnerable.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Maine — A million years ago, Stacy Mitchell was in her office, talking about why Amazon is bad for America.

articles.headline: The Food Chain’s Weakest Link: Slaughterhouses
articles.snippet: A relatively small number of plants process much of the beef and pork in the United States, and some of them have closed because workers are getting sick.
articles.abstract: A relatively small number of plants process much of the beef and pork in the United States, and some of them have closed because workers are getting sick.
articles.lead_paragraph: The modern American slaughterhouse is a very different place from the one that Upton Sinclair depicted in his early-20th-century novel, “The Jungle.”
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: A Key G.O.P. Strategy: Blame China. But Trump Goes Off Message.
articles.snippet: Republicans increasingly believe that elevating China’s culpability for spreading the coronavirus may be the best way to improve their difficult election chances. The president is muddying the message.
articles.abstract: Republicans increasingly believe that elevating China’s culpability for spreading the coronavirus may be the best way to improve their difficult election chances. The president is muddying the message.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The strategy could not be clearer: From the Republican lawmakers blanketing Fox News to new ads from President Trump’s super PAC to the biting criticism on Donald Trump Jr.’s Twitter feed, the G.O.P. is attempting to divert attention from the administration’s heavily criticized response to the coronavirus by pinning the blame on China.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: With Broad, Random Tests for Antibodies, Germany Seeks Path Out of Lockdown
articles.snippet: It was the first large Western democracy to contain the spread of the coronavirus and is now the first to methodically go about reopening its economy. Others are watching.
articles.abstract: It was the first large Western democracy to contain the spread of the coronavirus and is now the first to methodically go about reopening its economy. Others are watching.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Felix Germann was not expecting anyone when his doorbell rang last week. Outside was a doctor who looked like she had just stepped out of an operating theater, green scrubs, face mask and all — and a policeman.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and Laetitia Vancon

articles.headline: For Charlie Kirk, Conservative Activist, the Virus Is a Cudgel
articles.snippet: Mixing, matching and twisting facts about the coronavirus online, Mr. Kirk has created a template for a new kind of political agitator.
articles.abstract: Mixing, matching and twisting facts about the coronavirus online, Mr. Kirk has created a template for a new kind of political agitator.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly before midnight on Friday, and just hours after he had taken to Twitter to encourage Americans to “liberate” three Democratic-governed states from stay-at-home orders, President Trump reopened his Twitter app and went on another brief tear. He retweeted 11 posts by Charlie Kirk, a young right-wing provocateur with ties to the Trump family and a social media presence that attracts far more attention than some mainstream news organizations.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: Don’t Mention the Virus! And Other Marketing Tips
articles.snippet: Brands and influencers want to sell products to homebound customers, but doing so requires being sensitive to the reality of the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Brands and influencers want to sell products to homebound customers, but doing so requires being sensitive to the reality of the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic moved across the United States, the stock market plunged and many of the country’s businesses closed, a major platform for social media influencers had a rosier message: “Good news in consumer shopping trends!”

articles.headline: America’s Biggest Cities Were Already Losing Their Allure. What Happens Next?
articles.snippet: The urge among some residents to leave because of the coronavirus may be temporary. But it follows a deeper, more powerful demographic trend.
articles.abstract: The urge among some residents to leave because of the coronavirus may be temporary. But it follows a deeper, more powerful demographic trend.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before the coronavirus, Nina Brajovic wasn’t so sure about her life in New York. As a consultant for PricewaterhouseCoopers, she spent most weeks out of town traveling for work. She often wondered whether she could do her same job for cheaper — and more easily — while based in her hometown, Pittsburgh.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Sarah Mervosh

articles.headline: Antibody Test, Seen as Key to Reopening Country, Does Not Yet Deliver
articles.snippet: The tests, many made in China without F.D.A. approval, are often inaccurate. Some doctors are misusing them. The rollout is nowhere close to the demand.
articles.abstract: The tests, many made in China without F.D.A. approval, are often inaccurate. Some doctors are misusing them. The rollout is nowhere close to the demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: A law firm in Scottsdale, Ariz., tested employees who hoped, with the prick of a finger, to learn if they might be immune. In Laredo, Texas, community leaders secured 20,000 of the new tests to gauge how many residents had been infected. In Chicago, a hospital screened firefighters to help determine whether they could safely stay on the job.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder, Megan Twohey and Apoorva Mandavilli

articles.headline: Hollywood’s Specialized Backstage Workers Try to Soldier On
articles.snippet: Production has ground to a halt, leaving a vast number of people without work and others trying to figure out how to finish projects remotely.
articles.abstract: Production has ground to a halt, leaving a vast number of people without work and others trying to figure out how to finish projects remotely.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Just a few weeks ago, Hollywood’s global assembly lines were spinning at full speed.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: In Pandemic, a Remote Russian Region Orders a Lockdown on Information
articles.snippet: Trailing only Moscow in per capita infection, Komi faces a serious health crisis and wants to know who leaked the bad news.
articles.abstract: Trailing only Moscow in per capita infection, Komi faces a serious health crisis and wants to know who leaked the bad news.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Nearly as big as California but served by only a handful of mostly decrepit Soviet-era hospitals, the remote northern Russian region of Komi is a coronavirus petri dish for the horrors lying in wait for the world’s largest country.

articles.headline: The U.S. Tried to Teach China a Lesson About the Media. It Backfired.
articles.snippet: American journalists were showing the world the devastating effects of China’s botched response to the coronavirus. Now, many have been kicked out.
articles.abstract: American journalists were showing the world the devastating effects of China’s botched response to the coronavirus. Now, many have been kicked out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is better known for yelling at journalists than consoling them.

articles.headline: Zoom’s Security Woes Were No Secret to Business Partners Like Dropbox
articles.snippet: Dropbox privately paid top hackers to find bugs in software by the videoconferencing company Zoom, then pressed it to fix them.
articles.abstract: Dropbox privately paid top hackers to find bugs in software by the videoconferencing company Zoom, then pressed it to fix them.
articles.lead_paragraph: One year ago, two Australian hackers found themselves on an eight-hour flight to Singapore to attend a live hacking competition sponsored by Dropbox. At 30,000 feet, with nothing but a slow internet connection, they decided to get a head start by hacking Zoom, a videoconferencing service that they knew was used by many Dropbox employees.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: ‘The Big Guys Get Bailed Out’: Restaurants Vie for Relief Funds
articles.snippet: Shake Shack was among the larger companies criticized for seeking small-business emergency loans from the federal government.
articles.abstract: Shake Shack was among the larger companies criticized for seeking small-business emergency loans from the federal government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buried deep in the 900-page stimulus package that Congress passed in March, a single paragraph has sparked an outcry from small restaurants as major chains and mom-and-pop places alike scramble to survive a devastating financial crisis.
